conclusion: Understand the geometry of the wedge with a top angle of 30° and light refracting at 45°.
The angle between the incident ray from the light source and the tangent to the glass surface at point S is 30°.
The refracted ray makes an angle of 45° with the normal to the surface.
Consider triangle OSA with angles ∠OSA = 30°, ∠SAO = 45°, and ∠AOS = 105°.
Let the length of the edge be L, and the light-emitting part on the edge is along segment AB.
Use the sine rule in triangle OSA to find lengths: OS/sin 45° = OA/sin 105°.
Calculate OA using OS = x: OA = x(√6+√2)/(2√2).
Calculate length of light-emitting part AB: x(√3-1)/2.
Calculate ratio of light-emitting part to edge length L: (√3+1)/2.
Final ratio of the length of the light-emitting part on the edge to the length of the edge is (√3 + 1)/2.
